* more pull request cleanup

* more pull request cleanup

* more pull request cleanup

* more cleanup

* missing exception

* Added basic get, search and insert methods to the relationship DAO

* added upsert and delete methods to dao

* Added check for matching fields, currently the foreign key has to be the same name as the remote key

* Started on relationshipClasses tests and created wrapper so that MVC won't throw XStream exceptions

* Fixed faulty RelationshClass comparator, added in catalog save for altering metadatamap, and fleshed out add test

* Added in tests for getting relationshipclasses

* Added delete and update tests

* Added javadoc

* Added relationshipClass ID

* Fixed minor pull request issues

* Added comments to clarify RelationshipClass Comparator implementation and replaced relationshipClassId with a Long instead of a string

timeline.bodyText:
ESRI made a standard out of this API over here, we should do our best to reference GeoServices REST Specification in these docs:

http://geoservices.github.io/
http://www.openwebfoundation.org/

If we do use trademarked words such as ArcGIS and ESRI we should do so carefully and use a footer or something to acknowledge the trademark.
timeline.author: jodygarnett
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,109 @@
+Functionality
+=====================
+
+Currently basic FeatureServer and MapServer functionality work. Each GeoServer workspace is considered
+an ArcGIS "service" for the purposes of the API. ArcGIS URLs look like this in GeoServer:

replies.bodyText: Meeting notes, if we wish to use ArcGIS and ESRI we can do so, just note to use "tm" and sphinx footer
replies.author: jodygarnett

timeline.bodyText:
This should be standalone independent of js.arcgis.com
Can these examples be done with these resources https://esri.github.io/

replies.bodyText: Thanks for your suggestion, but I'm unable to retrieve those js and css from the resource you linked
replies.author: taba90

replies.bodyText: I only out a few moments search into it, the feedback remains that we need a way to include these examples in an open source project.
replies.author: jodygarnett

replies.bodyText:
Hmm... @jodygarnett  you do remember this is a community module right? :-D
Jokes aside, what bad can happen to js.arcgis.com that cannot also happen to esri.github.io?
They control contents in both?
Maybe what you're looking for can be found here: https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-js-api/releases/tag/4.5.0
But it's not minified, would have to be built anyways.
replies.author: aaime

replies.bodyText:
Ok, looks like we need to link to the source of the javascript too: https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-js-ap
And refer to it in the documentation?
replies.author: aaime

replies.bodyText:
Yeah it is a community module, so my feedback is only really for docs.
Good find, complete URL is https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-js-api
If we can mention the trademark for ESRI and ArcGIS we should be good, perhaps as a footnote? Or just some additional text.]
Here is some wording from osgeo website

ArcGIS Online® is a trademarks of Esri in the United States, the European Community, or certain other jurisdictions. Other companies and products mentioned may be trademarks of their respective owners.

So something similar for ArcGIS should do the trick.
replies.author: jodygarnett

replies.bodyText: thanks @jodygarnett  and @aaime I've added notes mentioning trademarks for ESRI and ArcGIS
replies.author: taba90

@@ -0,0 +1,104 @@
+Functionality
+=====================
+ 
+Formats
+---------------------------
+
+While the ArcGis implementation of GeoServices supports multiple file formats, all responses from the GeoServer plugin use JSON (for example, browser-friendly HTML is not provided.)  The ``?f=json`` parameter specifying JSON is still required.

timeline.bodyText: This section duplicates the other Capabilities list does it not?
timeline.author: jodygarnett
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,55 @@
+GSR Usage
+=====================
+
+Currently basic FeatureServer and MapServer functionality work. Each GeoServer workspace is considered
+an ArcGIS "service" for the purposes of the API. ArcGIS URLs look like this in GeoServer:
+
+http://localhost:8080/geoserver/gsr/services/topp/MapServer/
+http://localhost:8080/geoserver/gsr/services/topp/FeatureServer/
+
+Where topp is the workspace name.
+
+..note::  
+  Esri®, ArcGIS® and ArcGIS Online®  are trademarks, registered trademarks, or service marks of Esri in the United States, the European Community, or certain other jurisdictions. Other companies and products mentioned may be trademarks of their respective owners.
+
+
+CORS
+---------------------------
+
+When using the official JS API, CORS detection does not work correctly. You will need to add
+your server manually to the list of CORS enabled servers:
+
+.. code-block:: javascript
+
+  require(["esri/config"], function (esriConfig) {
+    esriConfig.request.corsEnabledServers.push("localhost:9191");
+  });
+
+CORS support also needs to be enabled on the server. Without these settings, it
+will attempt to use JSONP, which may not be as well supported.
+
+For information on enabling CORS in GeoServer, see [here](http://suite.opengeo.org/docs/latest/sysadmin/cors/index.html).
+
+Web Mercator Spatial Reference
+------------------------------
+
+The official APIs use Spatial Reference 102100 as Web Mercator. In order for this to work,
+add the following custom projection to your `data_dir/user_projections/epsg.properties` file:
+
+``102100=PROJCS["WGS 84 / Pseudo-Mercator",GEOGCS["Popular Visualisation CRS",
+DATUM["Popular_Visualisation_Datum",SPHEROID["Popular Visualisation Sphere",6378137,0,
+AUTHORITY["EPSG","7059"]],TOWGS84[0,0,0,0,0,0,0],AUTHORITY["EPSG","6055"]],
+PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,AUTHORITY["EPSG","8901"]],UNIT["degree",0.01745329251994328,
+AUTHORITY["EPSG","9122"]],AUTHORITY["EPSG","4055"]],UNIT["metre",1,AUTHORITY["EPSG","9001"]],
+PROJECTION["Mercator_1SP"],PARAMETER["central_meridian",0],PARAMETER["scale_factor",1],
+PARAMETER["false_easting",0],PARAMETER["false_northing",0],AUTHORITY["EPSG","3785"],
+AXIS["X",EAST],AXIS["Y",NORTH]]``
+
+Not supported
+------------------------------
+
+Notable features currently unsupported:
+
+- Non-geospatial filters
+- Dynamic layer definitions
+- Requests to feature layers in non-native spatial reference systems.

timeline.bodyText: Please use the NOTICE.md and LICENSE.md as appropriate (avoiding use of the txt versions)
timeline.author: jodygarnett

Basic implementation of MapService.  Still needs to address layers.

Avoid confusing JUnit

JsonSchemaTest is named like a test suite, but it is not a test suite.
This change prevents the JUnit test runner from erroring on this by
marking JsonSchemaTest abstract (thus not directly runnable.)

Tighten up test code

Avoid unnecessarily writing to a static field in the constructor of
JsonSchemaTest.
Use array initializer syntax instead of explicit assignment:
 { int[] a = { 1, 2 } }
instead of
 { int[] a = new int[2]; a[0] = 1; a[1] = 2 }
Merge remote-tracking branch 'ROGUE/mapservices' into gsr
Fix up compiler warnings in GSR module

Encode JTS Geometries directly

This is as opposed to using a custom Geometry hierarchy defined
specifically for the GeoServices API - with this we get better control
over JSON output and the ability to encode directly from GeoTools query
results without needing to translate between differing object models.
Include a bit more info in generic error

Initial Map Query operation

There's still a ways to go - filtering isn't supported yet in any form.
But this gets a JSON-lib based encoder working and demonstrates that
streaming output is possible.
Initial Query implementation

Add geometry filter support to Query

This only allows specifying the geometry, specifying the geospatial
relationship still remains to be done.  Also included in this changeset
is a basic decoder for JSON geometries.

Add error for 'text' query parameter

This feature relies on having a "display attribute" configured -
GeoServer doesn't have this concept, so for now we just error loudly.

Upgrade json-schema-validator to support building with maven 3

Upgrading the org.kitchen-eel:json-schema-validator version fixes
the build with maven 3, due to a known bug[1] that's fixed in newer
versions. Note that the org.kitchen-eel namespace has moved to
com.github.fge[2].

This also requires an upgrade of the guava version declared in
the root pom.xml, as required by json-schema-validator for which
guava is a dependency too. We're upgrading to 14.0.1 although
json-schema-validator requires 13.0.1 to also support the same
version that geogit uses.

[1] <https://github.com/fge/json-schema-validator/issues/39>
[2] <https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/json-schema-validator/V_lAFBOuTAY/dIJgC6lk_mgJ>

Updated upstream geoserver dependencies to include gs-prefix.

Also including some upstream module name changes.

remove explicit xstream dependency from gsr

Needed to update the version of xstream to resolve test failures.
Xstream gets pulled in transitively, so instead of explicitly pegging a
version, use the one that gets pulled in instead.
